Legal_Issue: Failure to adequately consider psychological report affecting credibility
Evidence_Assessment: Psychological report on PTSD not fully applied to explain inconsistencies
Decision_Outcome: Original refugee claim rejected based on credibility issues
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis for refugee claim
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony such as omissions and confusion about dates
Legal_Rule: The Board must consider all evidence, including psychological reports, when assessing credibility in refugee claims
Procedural_Issue: Board's failure to properly assess psychological evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: PTSD potentially affecting memory and testimony reliability
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim initially dismissed due to perceived lack of credibility
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Board did not provide adequate reasoning regarding impact of PTSD on testimony
Applicant_Challenge: Board failed to link PTSD diagnosis to credibility assessment
Court_Result: New hearing ordered with different panel
Legal_Rule_Source: Case law and statutory obligations under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of original decision and remittal for new hearing
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of IRPA (basis for refugee determination)
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada
Applicable_Process: Refugee protection division process and judicial review
Governing_Rule: Duty to consider all relevant evidence in credibility assessments
